RT @PM_nepal_: Rt. Hon. Prime Minister @SherBDeuba delivering his virtual speech at the 5th BIMESTEC summit in Sri Lanka. https://t.co/jvIr…

For a vibrant, forward-looking, and integrated BIMSTEC region, we must promote Buddhism as a strong connecting thread. We call for an early operationalization of the Buddhist circuit connecting Lumbini, the birthplace of Gautam Buddha.

Climate crisis has upset the ‘organic link’ between mountains and oceans.. We need bold climate action before the crisis passes the point of no return.

We must make the current crisis a gateway to a greener, safer, and more sustainable Bay of Bengal region.
Connectivity  plays a catalytic role for enhancing an effective regional process. We must enhance investment in transportation networks, energy, and power grid interconnections.

We must accelerate the implementation of the SDGs. 

It is more crucial for countries like Nepal, which are set to graduate from the LDC category.

Our race to resilience must start with a green and inclusive recovery plan.
 
This means action on vaccines, investment in health systems, and expansion of social protection schemes.

We must breathe new life into BIMSTEC and better frame the future of cooperation by pooling the strengths of all Member States.

Nepal remains committed, as ever, to contribute to the BIMSTEC process, says Rt Hon PM @SherBDeuba  in his address to the 5th BIMSTEC Summit.

We want to see a NAM that contributes to strengthening multilateralism with the United Nations at its centre- Prime Minister Rt Hon K P Sharma Oli said while addressing the 18th NAM Summit.
We want to see a NAM that takes up burning global issues in a systematic manner and devises concrete solutions to address them, said the PM.

We want to see a NAM that helps leverage the strength and capability of the South so that all developing nations build collective strengths to address development challenges to achieve shared prosperity.
We want to see a NAM that fosters goodwill, understanding and cooperation so that division and discord do not surface to undermine the unity of the Movement.

We want to see a NAM that is internally cohesive, united, strong and externally influential so that entrenched global inequalities are uprooted for once and for all, Prime Minister Rt Hon Oli said in his address to the NAM Summit.

Climate change has assumed crisis proportion. Being acutely aware of this fact, the Government of Nepal has decided to host the 'Sagarmatha Sambad', a global dialogue, under the theme of 'Mountains, Climate Change and the Future of Humanity' in April next year, said the PM

Comprehensive democracy demands a world order that is democratic, inclusive, just and fair. Unless and until we achieve it, the NAM will continue to be relevant for us. It is a synonym for peace, security, justice and development, said the Prime Minister.

Comprehensive democracy must be practiced at global level as well by ensuring sovereign equality, non-use of threat or force, non-interference in internal affairs, respect and dignity of all nations, non-exploitation and fair opportunities for all countries to grow and develop.

Human rights can find true meaning only in a condition of comprehensive democracy: holistic empowerment of individuals enjoys freedom from poverty, access to equal opportunity, right to life, security and dignity, stated the Prime Minister.
They make a perfect sync with the essence of Nepal's foreign policy principle that believes in 'Amity with all, enmity with none'.
We take immense pride in saying that the five principles of peaceful co-existence were derived from the teachings of Buddha, the immortal son of Nepal, said Prime Minister Oli.

Bandung principles manifested in the objectives of the NAM form the fundamentals of our foreign policy as enshrined in our Constitution, Prime Minister Rt Hon K P Sharma Oli stated while addressing the 18th NAM Summit.
In doing so, we wanted to preserve our autonomy in decision-making, which is the soul of sovereignty, said the Prime Minister.

It was a thoughtful decision to practice an independent foreign policy based on objective analysis away from biased judgement in an environment of intense East-West rivalry, Prime  Minister Rt Hon K  P Sharma Oli said in his statement.

NAM was conceived as a decisive response to unjust and unfair world where the basic essentials of human being- the freedoms were denied and suppressed and to defend fundamental rights of the peoples and the nations in the South, said the Prime Minister.
These principles are so sacrosanct and have timeless value that if we fail to observe them the world order will turn into anarchy, Prime Minister Rt. Hon. Mr. Oli said.

Sixty-four years ago, the leaders from Asia and Africa developed new set of principles to govern relations among nations. Those principles were about respecting and observing in good faith the principles of UN Charter, said the Prime Minister.

RT @PradeepgyawaliK: Nepal - Minister For Foreign Affairs Addresses General Debate, 74th Session https://t.co/ngDR0lRfzj
Only an empowered and reformed United Nations reflective of the present-day reality can achieve these critical responsibilities, -Foreign Minister Pradeep Kumar Gyawali.

We firmly believe in the centrality of the United Nations in promoting multilateralism.  
Viewing from the crossroads of history, we see no alternative to multilateralism to ensure peace, security and order in the world, said Foreign Minister Hon. Gyawali.
Lumbini in Nepal is not only the birthplace of Gautam Buddha, but also the fountain of peace. We want to promote this world heritage at the international stage, said the Foreign Minister.

Nepal’s democratic transformation presents a uniquely successful, nationally led and owned peace process. We would be happy to share our experience that may be useful to those in conflict, said Foreign Minister Gyawali.
We believe in an inclusive, just and fair international order.
We greatly count on the valuable support of all UN member States to the candidature of Nepal for re-election to the Human Rights Council, Hon. Foreign Minister.

We are fully committed to concluding the transitional justice process in line with CPA, directive of the Supreme Court, relevant international commitments, concerns of the victims and the ground realities, said Foreign Minister Gyawali.
The Constitution of Nepal is founded on the fundamentals of inclusive democracy, pluralism, rule of law, secularism, representative and accountable government, social justice, and human rights.
Nepal’s commitment to the universal values of human rights is total.
As a host to a large number of refugees for decades, Nepal firmly believes in refugees’ right to return to their home country in safety and dignity- Foreign Minister Hon. Pradeep Kumar Gyawali.
Ensuring the rights and wellbeing of the migrant workers is a matter of our priority, said Foreign Minister Gyawali.

Our peacekeepers have been deployed even in fragile and asymmetric threat environments. Safety, security and dignity of peacekeepers is therefore critically important for us, said Foreign Minister Gyawali.
Nepal has rendered one of the most dedicated, reliable and professional services to the UN peace operations for over six decades- Minister Gyawali.

Nepal welcomes the dialogues between the United Sates and DPRK and between the two Koreas. We hope the initiatives will lead to lasting peace and stability on the Korean peninsula, said Foreign Minister Hon. Pradeep Kumar Gyawali.
We support a two-state solution for Israel and Palestine, living side by side in peace and security with secure and recognized international borders based on relevant United Nations resolutions.
We believe in peaceful settlement of conflicts and disputes through negotiations and dialogues, and without external interferences- Foreign Minister Gyawali.
Nepal condemns terrorism in all its forms and manifestations. We call for effective implementation of existing conventions and resolutions, says Foreign Minister Hon. Gyawali.

As the host country to the UNRCPD Nepal calls for strengthening of the regional approaches to disarmament including the ‘Kathmandu Process’ to complement the global initiatives, said Minister Gyawali.
We stand for a legally binding multilateral disarmament regime for ensuring global security and stability -Minister Gyawali.
We are concerned with the collapse of INF treaty, pull out of an important party from the Iran Nuclear deal, and stalemate in the Conference on Disarmament, said Foreign Minister Gyawali.
Nepal supports general and complete disarmament of all weapons of mass destruction- Foreign  Minister Gyawali.
Heightened geopolitical complexities, defunct disarmament architecture, and absence of order in cyber and outer space endanger international peace and stability, said Minister Gyawali.
The agenda of revitalizing the work of the General Assembly, including its enhanced role and authority is long overdue. We must take this reform with priority- Foreign Minister Gyawali.
Our efforts must be towards making the Security Council representative in structure, transparent in function, democratic in character and accountable in performance, Foreign Minister Gyawali.
Nepal welcomes the reforms towards creating synergy and coherence of the UN system adhering to the principle of keeping people at the centre, said Foreign Minister Gyawali. https://t.co/5QLxmNFjRF
Women and girls, people with disabilities, ageing population still bear the disproportionate brunt of poverty and inequalities, says Minister Gyawali.
To fill resource gap for SDGs, national efforts need to be complemented by international support measures to the LDCs and LLDCs, said Foreign Minister Gyawali.
Adoption of the Agenda 2030 was a display of inclusive multilateralism at its best. It can be implemented if similar spirit guides our actions with renewed partnership, says Foreign Minister Gyawali.
We have abiding trust on multilateralism and we believe that only alternative to it is a better, effective, inclusive, and responsive multilateralism, said Foreign Minister Gyawali.
Nepal pins a great hope on the centrality of the UN for galvanizing multilateral efforts to address the global challenges, said Minister Gyawali. https://t.co/mkYfiaLlPR
Keeping in mind the seriousness of climate change, the first episode of Sagarmatha Dialogue to be held in April next year will be dedicated to it, said Foreign  Minister Gyawali.
Home to Sagarmatha, also known as the Mount Everest, Nepal lies at the hotspot of climate change- Foreign Minister Hon. Gyawali. https://t.co/luMEedtJ16
Despite their negligible emissions, the poorest countries face the consequences which are disproportionate, unjust and undue, said Hon. Gyawali.
The peril of climate change is outpacing our response. The threat is truly existential in terms of sustainability of planet and future of humanity - Foreign Minister Gyawali.

"Trade tensions among the largest economies are giving rise to unpredictability and risk of recession. The ensuing insecurity and disorder hurt the countries such as LDCs the most", said Minister Gyawali.

The world today stands at crossroads. Landscapes of global order are undergoing profound transformation. The problems of yesterday haven’t subsided, yet new challenges are menacing, says Foreign Minister Gyawali.

RT @ilo: Nepal Prime Minister @kpsharmaoli underlined sustainability in his address to the Centenary Session of the International Labour Co…
Prime Minister Rt Hon K P Sharma Oli while addressing the High Level Centenary Session of the ILO. https://t.co/bqfzpfQK7V
Let us deliberate on how ILO can secure its own future and the future of its tripartite constituents, the Prime Minister concluded the statement.

Today is the time to uphold ILO's founding ideals and demonstrate that they continue to be relevant in furthering the value of human worth, equality, social justice and sustainable future, the Prime Minister stated.

Hundred years on, the preambular words of the ILO’s Constitution continue to resonate in this assembly hall calling for reaffirmation to social justice and lasting peace. We must meet these ‘moral-minimum’ and move forward to address more pressing issues of our time, PM said.

In this context, we want to define it as- सक्षमश्रमिक, समृद्धनेपाल, सुखीनेपाली – meaning 'skilled workers, prosperous Nepal, happy Nepali' to underpin our agenda for decent work, wage and workplace, said the Prime Minister.

Over five decades of my public life, I have fought for equality and social justice for our people. The Government under my leadership is focused on realizing the national aspiration of ‘Prosperous Nepal, Happy Nepali’.

Nepal’s own democratic struggles drew significant inspiration from the work of ILO as many of our trade union leaders were the torchbearers of resistance against autocracy and pioneer of the democratic movements, said the Prime Minister.

The world of work in Nepal has voluntarily evolved a social contract to implement rights related issue and engage in collective agreements to safeguard the interests, Prime Minister Rt Hon K P Sharma Oli said.
The Government ensures employer’scompliance throughlabour audit that provides an opportunity for reflection, self-assessment and improvement.
Presence of tripartite forum at the centre has resulted in improved labour relations that have brought down the labour disputes almost to nought, said the Rt Hon Prime Minister.
This distinct forum of workers represents all working people in Nepal to engage in social dialogue and promotes their interest in a spirit of solidarity and harmonious labour relations.

We have created institutional framework for social dialogue at federal, provincial, local and enterprise levels.
Through a common platform of Joint Trade Union Coordination Centre, Nepal practices a unique example of unity in diversity of trade unions, said the Prime Minister.
Migrant workers are often vulnerable to high recruitment costs, contract substitution, unsafe and unsecured working conditions, and non-compliance of terms of employment, said the Prime Minister.
Enterprises are the drivers of modern economy that provide jobs and implement ILO standards. Our actions should support them to grow, create more jobs, and sustain economy, the Prime Minister stated.
Inclusion remains a basic tenet of our polity. Special measures are in place to ensure inclusion of all sections of our society in the State organs, the Prime Minister said.

This year in February, we launched Prime Minister Employment Program. The program aims to create jobs, guarantees employment to every working age citizen, provides allowances in case of unemployment, promotes innovation and entrepreneurship, and supports skilling, re-skilling.

For past 25 years, Nepal has been providing old age pension to the senior citizens, and monthly allowances to single women and those coming from the most marginalized section of our society, said the Prime Minister.

Last year in November, we launched a comprehensive social security scheme to the working people. This largest ever social security undertaking in Nepal covers benefits such as unemployment, maternity, sickness, old age, accident, dependent family members, and disability.

The entire life of an individual is covered by social security system.  In childhood and old age, the State provides universal social security. In active age, workers are protected through contribution-based social security, said the Prime Minister.
We have enacted a number of implementing legislations to enforce the fundamental rights, including those related to the world of work.

Our Constitution embodies social justice, right against exploitation, rights to work, remuneration and social security as well as right to trade union and collective bargaining, the Prime Minister said.
Ours is a comprehensive democracy that empowers individual in all dimensions- political, economic, social and cultural, he said.
Democracy without economic right and social justice remains incomplete, said the Prime Minister.

"Nepal’s democratic Constitution is founded on the ideals of equality, non-discrimination, and social justice," Prime Minister RT. Hon K P Sharma Oli said while addressing the Centenary Session of the ILO.

We redefined the notion of life-long job by social protection to all workers irrespective of their nature of job; ensured fair balance between flexibility and social security; and legally ended the dichotomy of formal vs. informal sector, said the Prime Minister.
Our laws do not discriminate workers on the basis of their status - regular or irregular, outsourced or contractual and those coming from organized or informal sector, the Prime Minister said.
We have adopted firm legal and policy reforms to address the dynamic international labour environment.
Nepal is endowed with vast natural resources as well as rich demographic dividend. This makes future of the world of work in Nepal highly promising, said the Prime Minister.
Persistent unemployment of youth breeds political instability and engenders poverty. We must end this situation, Prime Minister Rt Hon Oli said.
Labour is not a commodity. ILO has a role to play that core principles of Philadelphia Declaration areupheld at all times, said Rt Hon Prime Minister.
Adequate wages and time sovereignty go hand in hand. That is the sign of prosperity and wellbeing of all workers.
The Rt. Hon. Prime said that the climate change is raising demands in green jobs, climate actions will be most effective if they begin at the world of work.
We must ensure gender equality, strengthen social protection, respect social dialogue, and guarantee rights at work, stated the Prime Minister.
To manage changes, we must keep human at the centre of all and I invest in people’s capabilities, promote entrepreneurship and create decent jobs, Rt. Hon. PM Oli said.

This also provides an opportunity that we handover a liveable planet to our posterity and create a win-win situation through demographic dividend to supplement where human capital is in short supply, said PM Oli.

However, every change comes with new opportunities and challenges. This provides an opportunity to define that our destiny remains at the human command, but not at the command of technology, said the Prime  Minister.
Technology has replaced traditional jobs, transformed the way we work, and created more innovative workplaces, said the Prime Minister.

Prime Minister Rt. Hon. Oli said- development of technology, shifting demography, migration and change in the organization of work are creating new paths to prosperity. They are also disrupting the existing work arrangements.
The report of the Global Commission on the Future of Work will set a discourse for another quarter of a century, said the Prime Minister.

The Prime Minister stated -the core principles that ILO advanced, such as equal pay for equal value of work, freedom of association, working hours, adequate wage for living, balance between work and life, and social protection are its unique contributions to human civilization.
The ILO’s Constitution was framed in the ashes of the First World War. It reflected the collective desire and commitment of humanity to peace through social dialogue, the Prime Minister said.
This centenary celebration of the International Labour Organization is a celebration of the rights of the toiling masses to social justice through social dialogue, said the Prime Minister.

We know that no country has ever achieved perfection in human rights. What is important is how sincerely & seriously we are aiming higher & better. Nepal has been consistently doing better and we are genuinely willing to improve further- Foreign Minister Gyawali. @PradeepgyawaliK

Our experience in the Council has given much needed confidence to consolidate democracy, peace and human rights in the country. With this in mind, Nepal has presented candidature for the re-election to the Council for the second term 2021-2023, said Foreign Minister Gyawali.

In doing so, we will be guided by Comprehensive Peace Accord, directive of the Supreme Court, relevant int'l commitments, concerns of the victims and ground realities. There will be no blanket amnesty in the cases of serious violations of human rights- Foreign Minister Gyawali.
There exists a requisite political will to conclude this last remaining task of the peace process in equally unique way, said Minister Gyawali. @PradeepgyawaliK @bairagi_shanker @PaudyalBR

Nepal is a uniquely successful case of nationally owned and nationally led peace process. To conclude the last leg of this process, term of the two independent Commissions have been recently extended to allow time to complete their mandates- FM @PradeepgyawaliK @bairagi_shanker

The story of gender equality and empowerment is inspiring. Women now represent 33 per cent at the federal and provincial assemblies, and total 41% in all elected bodies. Nepal currently has a woman Head of State, said Foreign Minister Gyawali.@PradeepgyawaliK @bairagi_shanker

Having firmly set the political course in place, we are resolutely focused on economic agenda with the long term vision of “Prosperous Nepal, Happy Nepali”. We are in the mission of enabling our people to fully enjoy all human rights- Foreign Minister Gyawali. @PradeepgyawaliK

The year 2018 essentially remained a year of human rights law making. We accomplished the task of enacting total 16 legislations for the implementation of all fundamental rights enshrined in the Constitution- Foreign Minister Gyawali.@PradeepgyawaliK @bairagi_shanker @PaudyalBR

The Constitution of Nepal is founded on universally recognized human rights and fundamental freedoms. Equality and non-discrimination lie at the core of it, said Foreign Minister Gyawali.@PradeepgyawaliK @bairagi_shanker @PaudyalBR

Nepal’s commitment to the universal values of human rights is total. We are a party to all major international human rights instruments, including seven of the nine core human rights conventions. We have internalized those values into our national laws, policies and practices.

Nepal represents a uniquely successful case of democratic political transformation.  At the center of this process lies our aspiration to ensure equal rights to all of our people- Foreign Minister Gyawali.@PradeepgyawaliK @bairagi_shanker @PaudyalBR

The work of this Council should rekindle a hope for all those that look upon us as a voice of conscience. Our commitment and action should speak in harmony, said Foreign Minister Gyawali. @PradeepgyawaliK @bairagi_shanker @PaudyalBR

Peace and human rights cannot be achieved without attaining inclusive development. We consider that the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development and Global Compact on Migration provide wider platforms to advance inclusive human rights agenda everywhere, said Foreign Minister.
Foreign Minister Hon Pradeep Kumar Gyawali addressing the UN Human Rights Council. https://t.co/EL1xhO4Gnf

Our approach must remain balanced and all human rights must be operational at national, regional and international levels. The rule of law must work at all levels, said Foreign Minister Hon Pradeep Kumar Gyawali while addressing the Human Rights Council. @PradeepgyawaliK

All human rights must be treated in a fair and equal manner on the same footing and with the same emphasis, Foreign Minister Gyawali while addressing the 4oth session of HRC- Foreign Minister Gyawali @PradeepgyawaliK @bairagi_shanker

We firmly believe in the universality, indivisibility, interrelatedness, interdependence and mutually reinforcing nature of human rights, including the right to development, says Foreign Minister Hon Gyawali. @PradeepgyawaliK @bairagi_shanker @PaudyalBR

21st Century's history should be that of cooperation and harmony; of prosperity, inclusion and development; and of justice and fairness, said Prime Minister Oli.

21st century history should not be written as a history of confrontation n conflict; of poverty, exclusion and under-development; of injustice and exploitation, Prime Minister Rt Hon K.P Sharma Oli said at the UNGA.

It is obligation of all Member States to preserve the sanctity of multilateralism and uphold respect for international law. The problems that we confront today at global scale can only be overcome by global collaboration and partnership in absolute trust and confidence- PM Oli.

Nepal’s commitment to the protection and promotion of human rights is total and unflinching. We hold that development, democracy and respect for human rights as interdependent and mutually reinforcing, said Prime Minister Rt Hon K.P Sharma Oli while addressing the UNGA.

Ensuring human rights and wellbeing of all migrant workers remain our priority. Nepal believes that the Compact will serve this purpose and make migration work for all- said Prime Minister Rt Hon K.P. Sharma Oli.

Nepal welcomes the reforms undertaken in peace and security architecture as well as management of the organization. UN should reflect the mosaic of its membership, and achieve greater efficiency and effectiveness, said Prime Minister Rt Hon K.P Sharma Oli addressing 73rd UNGA.

We believe that the repositioned UN development system will better deliver on 2030 Agenda. To ensure a sound system, learning the new methods by a new generation of Country Teams is important. But more than that unlearning the old habits is equally important, said PM Oli.
 .

Health and wellbeing of our children and youths is an investment for future. Delivering quality education, imparting skills, and spurring innovation can make a virtuous composite to enable youths be relevant and be able to contribute to society and nation building, said PM Oli.
Reaching furthest behind first is not a luxury. It is not a charity either. It is an international obligation, a duty and social responsibility, said PM Oli.

Development in LDCs appears dismal despite a record performance of global economy. International support measures are failing to make a dent. Implementation of the internationally agreed commitments made in their favour is far below our expectation, said Prime Minister Oli.

We must ensure that the voice of the people struggling for their rights, liberty, freedom and justice in various parts of the world, including Syria, Yemen, Palestine, and many other places must be heard and addressed, said Prime Minister Rt Hon K.P Sharma Oli.

Challenges ranging from poverty, terrorism, climate change, food insecurity, forced displacement and natural disasters to arms race continue to confront the global community. Intra-sate conflicts have taken heavy toll on millions of lives, said Prime Minister Oli.

Our foreign policy guides us to maintain amity with all and enmity with none. It has shaped our independent outlook on global issues which we consider on merit basis, said Prime Minister Rt Hon K.P Sharma Oli.

Nepal's vision for 'Prosperous Nepal and Happy Nepali' will be realized with right mix of prudent utilization of natural resources and the optimal mobilization and management of human resources that we are endowed with, said Prime Minister Oli.

We have laid the foundation towards creating an egalitarian and just society where all citizens are treated equally and receive equal protection and opportunities. Social justice remains at the center of our polity, said PM Rt Hon K.P Sharma Oli while addressing the UNGA.

We accomplished implementing   Constitution through free, fair and impartial elections with record turnout of people from all sections of our society. The elections brought 41% of women into elected bodies. We remain committed to bridging gap of the remaining 9 percent- PM Oli.

Constitution of Nepal consolidates democratic polity, embodies rights and freedoms. Separation of power, checks and balances, rule of law, independence of judiciary, periodic elections, inclusive and proportional representation are defining features of the Constitution- PM Oli.

Since I addressed from this podium in 2006, Nepal has undergone historic political transformation. Through dialogue and deliberations, mutual respect and accommodation, we steered a uniquely successful home-grown, nationally led and owned peace process, said Prime Minister Oli.

Nepal’s commitment to democracy and fundamental freedoms is total. The long journey of our political struggle is synonymous to the struggle for democracy. We believe that democracy, development and respect for human rights are interdependent n mutually reinforcing, said PM Oli.

Nepal's efforts will be to promoting a rule-based, just and equitable int'l order in which all States- small and big- fulfill their int'l obligations in good faith, n all countries enjoy equitable opportunities to fulfill aspirations for development and prosperity, said PM Oli.

Our relations with major powers and development partners have been all along cordial and friendly. We would like to further develop and expand our cooperative partnership with them. Extended neighbourhood and labour destination countries are also in our foreign policy priority.

We enjoy cordial and friendly relations with both our immediate neighbours, India and China. Economic growth and prosperity in neighbourhood offer us a promising prospect for the development of our country, said Prime Minister Rt Hon K.P Sharma Oli.

Amity with all, and enmity with none remains at the heart of Nepal’s foreign policy.  This is inspired by the principles of UN Charter, Panchasheel, non-alignment, international law, and norms of world peace, said the Prime Minister while outlining Nepal's Foreign Policy.

Our aim is to attain a comprehensive democracy that empowers individuals in all spheres of national life- political, economic, social and cultural. I have a conviction that full realization of SDGs, makes this possible, said Prime Minister Rt Hon K.P Sharma Oli.

To sustain the political gains and deliver on the development dividend to our people, my Government has set a long-term goal of “Prosperous Nepal and Happy Nepali”. We must:
- Eradicate poverty, 
- Eliminate inequality,,
- Ensure social justice,
- Promote good governance.

But our fight is continuing in a different form; as a fight against poverty, underdevelopment and backwardness, said PM Rt. Hon. Oli.

We are serious to ensure that the TJ process is fair and free from pressure and influences -both from within and outside the country.

To fully address the issue of transitional justice, two Commissions are currently engaged in the country. I reiterate that there should be no blanket amnesty to serious violations of human rights and humanitarian laws, said the Prime Minister.
We consider that by attaining economic development and providing means of implementation of human rights obligations create enabling environment for the enjoyment of human rights by all.

As a member of HRC, we will provide a strong voice to all those around the globe who look up to the Council to make a positive difference in their lives. Nepal will always stand for apolitical and objective examination of human rights issues, the Prime Minister said.
Nepal will continue contributing to the maintenance of international peace and security through its effective participation in UN mandated peacekeeping operations, said the Rt. Hon. Prime Minister.

We support the UN reform initiatives to provide equal emphasis on all three pillars- peace and security, development and human rights, and to make the world body more efficient, effective and responsive of the need of our time.

We fully acknowledge the support and cooperation received from our development partners. 
We urge the development partners to align assistance with our priorities, respecting our leadership & ownership in the process and channelizing such support through government mechanisms.
We respect the legitimate interests of our neighbours and will not allow anything against them in our soil.
We are thankful for all the goodwill and support of our neighbors towards our national aspirations. We look forward to further strengthening these relations at all levels of our cooperation.
The Prime Minister said, we enjoy cordial and friendly relation with both our immediate neighbors, India and China. Mutual trust will be the key ingredient of our relationship.
Our motto will be ‘amity with all, and enmity with none’.  We want to be a good friend of everyone and we want to treat everyone as a good friend.
The Rt. Hon. Prime Minister said- we will be guided by the principles of Panchasheel, non-alignment, UN Charter, international law, and norms of world peace in the conduct of our foreign relations.
Independent foreign policy and balanced conduct of relations will be the hallmarks of our external engagements.

As the people of a country that was never under the control of any external power, we hold, more than anything else, the principles of sovereignty, independence and non-interference close to our heart.

Promoting the image of Nepal as an inclusive democratic State at the international level as well as advancing the cause of Nepal’s socio-economic development will remain our two intrinsic diplomatic goals, pronounced the Prime Minister.

Rule of law will be at the centre of governance and will be pursued in an effective manner. We will also pursue a policy of zero-tolerance against corruption. Our aim is to ensure corruption-free governance- the PM explained the priority of the Government.

We do not want to see our people exploited under any ulterior agenda. We will stand united and pull our resources together to defeat the forces of divisions and instability and work for the betterment of our people.

There is no space for violence in our society. There might be some attempts from different quarters to disrupt our social harmony and cohesion under various pretexts. There might be some elements who believe in perpetuity of conflict and discord in our society, says the PM.
Inclusive polity has been the true spirit of our constitution and we want to implement it in earnest.

We cannot imagine sustainable peace and prosperity without social justice based on equality.
Ours is a society full of diversity. Unity in diversity has been a Nepali characteristic and a primary source of our strength, the Prime Minister said.
We believe that democracy is irreversible and no one can snatch it now from us, said Prime Minister Rt. Hon. Oli.

We are committed to safeguarding independent and sovereign space for the benefit of our national interest and for the good of our posterity. This comes as a non-negotiable priority for us, the Prime Minister underlined.
We Nepalis are a proud people with our long and glorious history of independence and sovereignty.
The first one is nationalism. We understand nationalism as the protection of our sovereignty, territorial integrity, national independence, and fulfilment of our national interest- said the PM.
The present government has the motto of ‘Prosperous Nepal and happy Nepali.’ Its policies and programmes will be founded on six fundamental pillars, said Rt. Hon. Prime Minister K.P. Sharma Oli.

We have entered into an era of political stability. We have paid heavy price to reach this stage.  We believe that our friends and well-wishers who want to see a peaceful, stable and prosperous Nepal also cherish this historic achievement of the people of Nepal- PM Rt. Hon. Oli.

I am happy to share with you that we have been able to ensure over 41 per cent of women representation in elected bodies. This is not a small achievement by any standard. We will make further efforts to bridge the gap of remaining 9 per cent, says the Prime Minister.

Nepal has undergone transformation of historic proportions in the past one decade. The impact of transformation has not only confined to political sphere but also has been felt across all spheres of national life, said Prime Minister Rt. Hon. Oli.
Ptime Minister Rt. Hon. K.P. Sharma Oli addressing the diplomatic community in Kathmandu. https://t.co/5ghO8EVcBt

Nepal has always maintained cordial relations with all countries in the world. We have historically enjoyed very close relations with our immediate neighbours- Foreign Minister Gyawali.
